thread.title: Giving a nod to new ways to fight poverty
thread.title_full: Giving a nod to new ways to fight poverty

author: democratandchronicle.com
title: Giving a nod to new ways to fight poverty
text:
But Brock wants people to extend themselves. In a speech that touched on his childhood in one of Rochester's poorest sections and summarized the much-anticipated first report of the poverty initiative, Brock was most animated and adamant when rolling out a multipoint plan for community involvement: "Everyone give, even if it's a dollar to give, and give monthly," he said. Recruit 25 people to do the same to support a community-owned and operated initiative, business or charity.
"Make a commitment to build a relationship with one person that's not part of your natural network," he admonished about 400 people who likely all knew or knew of each other before they sat down at their tables of 10. "Diversify your networks. Your network is your net worth. Make it a priority to spend time with people of different backgrounds, experiences and ideologies."
But as he said, the reports and data created from decades of meetings held to find solutions haven't done much other than reconfirm Rochester's poverty problem.
"We have to challenge the status quo," he said.
From what I see on many sidewalks I travel, the first step is nodding to the person going the other way.
Patti Singer is the Clean Living reporter for the Democrat and Chronicle . She has been covering the Rochester-Monroe Anti-Poverty Initiative since it was formed in January. This first appeared in her All About Health blog. Follow her @PattiSingerRoc.
Leonard Brock says entire community is needed to find solutions that will make a difference. Video by Patti Singer
